Posts.Content: So sorry to hear of your diagnosis - IBC is very unpleasant. If you haven't already found it, here is a site about it: http://www.ibcresearch.org/ What treatment are you going to be having?
Posts.Title: Imflamatory Breast Cancer

Posts.Content: Hi - it's always worrying when spread happens. All I can say is that there have been indications of development in liver, abdomen and bone in my CT scans, but that chemo has so far either knocked them back or held them static. Hormone treatment failed in my case to hold or reduce it. We are all different, so my experience is just that, and may have no bearing on what will work for your mum. However, it does show that secondaries can be contained.
Posts.Title: secondary cancer liver and bones

Posts.Content: Ignore snakeoil sales pitches - to find out about HER and its relevance to you, have a look at this site : http://www.breastcancer.org/cmty_trans_2005_11.html

Posts.Content: Hi - it horrifies me that this kind of information is not automatically given to newly diagnosed patients when they start treatment. Despite any faults it may have, the NHS does provide it and all the clinics have leaflets about equipment and clothing. However, I have found the breast cancer sites helpful as well, and in case you haven't tracked them down yet, to start you off here is an Australian one: http://www.bcna.org.au/content/view/763/1337/ and an American one: http://www.breastcancer.org/

Posts.Content: Hi, sam21, it may be a simple skin growth that can be easily removed. Your best course of action is to see your GP and tell him/her your concern. It does not sound like a breast cancer, which does not as a rule present externally in this way, but rather than worry and do nothing, have it looked at. Let us know how you get on.

Posts.Content: Well, acupuncture may help, so it is worth a try. The other thing to try is ginger, which has an ancient history of helping to control nausea. See here for more information: http://www.webmd.com/cancer/news/200...oot-out-nausea http://www.medicalnewstoday.com/articles/150176.php

Posts.Content: Update: My blood counts have remained almost normal, and the nurses tell me they think that is the effect of the honey, so I am continuing it. However, I have the dreaded hands and feet syndrome, with cracking skin on the fingers and toes, on the edge of the nails. AGONY!!! Anhyone who has had the same problem - how did you cope??
Posts.Title: On the move again.

Posts.Content: Update - Today we decided to stop the capecitabine. The toxicity outweighs the benefits. Sad, but frankly life has been pretty intolerable, with sore, cracking hands and sore, cracked feet making movement difficult. The last blood counts were against me, so the decision had to be taken. Onwards and upwards! Probably back to trying hormonals for a while. Fortunately it is a very slow cancer, so my onc. is hopeful. I have been taking the Lifemel honey, but clearly it has not really been of major help so I will probably stop that as well. Disappointing, but one alwys hopes for the best. I do wonder if there could be DNA tests developed to indicate how individuals might respond to chemos.
Posts.Title: On the move again.

Posts.Content: Everybody dies in the end. Chemo has helped me to survive longer than I probably would without, careful diet notwithstanding. It is not fair to frighten people about treatments. They are not pleasant treatments, but they do have a place. There is increasing evidence that your genetic makeup is at the root of cancer as a disease, just as there is increasing evidence that your genetic makeup controls your length of life. There is NO evidence that diet will do what chemo or radiotherapy can do.

Posts.Title: Breast Cancer Reccurance - treatment

Posts.Content: Hi Shirley. This is very common. I am always aware that I interpret sensations and reactions into possible development of new cancers. Being aware that I am dong this does not stop me. So far [touching wood in all directions] it has never been the case. I am afraid it is part of the problem of being a cancer victim. If you can, find someone you can talk to. Often the fear is bound up with keeping the fear to yourself and talking it out can help. I also feel that it is very important to keep busy on things that have nothing to do with cancer. If these fears and depression have suddenly returned, maybe you should step back and look at what is happening in your life generally? Keep talking here - others will have their own views and suggestions.
Posts.Title: Delayed reaction

Posts.Content: Alas, my skin mets are not responding to hormone treatment, so I am moving into chemo again. Capecitabine is the one chosen. This was triggered as there has been a tumour development in the skin under one eye, and it is affecting the eye movement. Since the danger is that I will be stopped from driving - and I cannot at present afford to be in that situation, aggressive action must be taken to reduce these growths. For those that are interested, I am [with my oncologist's agreement] also trying this special honey from Israel which is supposed to mitigate the side effects and improve the efficacy of the treatment. I will let you know what happens.
Posts.Title: On the move again.

Posts.Content: Hi - I'm sorry about your friend. It is a sign that the cancer has progressed to a massive degree, and usually is a sign that things are coming to a close. Generally the only thing that is done is to dress the lesions and keep the patient as comfortable as possible. You say she is in an institution. Is there any chance that you - or her sister - b can consult with the medical staff as to what can be provided in supplementaries? They may not lead to a cure, but they may help her system to cope with the problems.
Posts.Title: Breast Cancer Eruption from Skin

Posts.Content: Hi, Eleanor. Don't feel guilty. It is natural to want someone close to you not to suffer. What amazes me so often is the way in which the body keeps going, despite all the problems. You are also tired and need to consider yourself. I truly believe that your mother will know when she wants to let go, and that you will need to be ready to tell her that she can. Keep talking to us - we are here to give you support.

Posts.Content: Thanks, Angie. I was meaning a test to establish what treatments will suit an individual with the minimum of dangerous or uncomfortable side effect. Maybe genetic testing is a better term. An Oxford company has been working on this idea, but it still costs a horrendous amount to implement, and has not been properly tested. A major breakthrough has been achieved to do with HIV, where the leukocytes have been altered to recognise all forms of the virus and to attack it in any form. It seems to me that this could also be a first step towards developing cells that will recognise cancer in any form and that will then attack them. Maybe not in my lifetime, but a real small glimpse of a possible future.

My highly experienced and very open-minded oncologist seems not to have met (or even heard of) these people nor to have encountered the means of curing. I have no intention of paying good money for this sort of nonsense, and I would encourage others to think carefully before parting with a penny.

Posts.Content: Chemos have all sorts of side-effects, and these do change as the body adapts to the effect of the chemo. The doctors should be made aware if she is having problems. Mouth sores can be helped by a solution of bicarbonate of soda [baking soda] - 1 part b/soda to 10 parts warm water. It does no harm if swallowed and is very effective on mouth problems.

Posts.Content: Hi suzique - presumably you had a calcification in the breast (very common), and a biopsy has shown that it is cancerous. You will be referred to an oncology team [specialists in cancer and its treatment] for the next step. You should ask your medical team whether it is hormone positive or negative - this influences treatment plans - and what stage it is at. But it sounds as though it has been caught early, so you will have an excellent chance of recovery. When will you be seeing the oncologists?

Posts.Title: Mira looma

Posts.Content: Anne-rules - You can always seek a second opinion - not all experts agree on treatment approaches. Also, as a general point, any breast cancer that has reached stage IV is described as "terminal". It is not a pointer to rapid death. It is the way in which the disease is described. I have been terminal for 4 years and plan to be around for a while longer. I would encourage you to see if you can get your mother to seek referral to another hospital if at all possible.

Posts.Content: Thank you for this. Good plain moderate diet combined with good plain moderate exercise is to be highly recommended for building the system to prevent any form of infection taking hold, even the head cold. A hour of gardening is as good as any treadmill, and in some ways better; so too is housework [without mechanical aids]. Aqua aerobics is a superb method of maintaining fitness. Taking dogs for walks gives a purpose to walking for 20 minutes.
Posts.Title: Prevention is better than cure.

Posts.Content: There can be a hereditary link in breast cancer, but in your case it seems unlikely that there is one. As to what triggers it, that is the great question that thousands of scientists are trying to answer. Genetics and hormones are two strong suspects. As Muttsmom says, eating a good diet is always a good thing, and being aware of your own body is vital. Equally, worrying about whether you are developing cancer is a negative activity. Try not to think about it. It sometimes seems that everyone is developing it, but in fact statistically there are many more people who do not have cancer that do have it. As to treatments, don't knock chemo - it can be unpleasant, but it has kept me alive. The nasty effects are relatively temporary, and if the cancer is stopped in its tracks, it is worth it. With reference to your father-in-law, Primary lung cancers are very difficult as they are generally not diagnosed until late in their development, when it becomes impossible to use surgery. There are new treatments being tested which are showing good results. The essential thing with bc is early diagnosis. The quicker it is caught, the better. If your doctor wants you to have regular mammograms, then go with it. But also ask about ultrasound testing as an alternative.
Posts.Title: Is it really hereditary?

Posts.Content: I have not heard of this before. Where did your scan take place?
Posts.Title: Mira looma

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by jeniffer1 Hi, I am 27 year old and I got married last year. None of my family member ever had Breast cancer problem. So, is there any chance that I may face these serious disease in the future. I am really worried about it. Please help!!! Who can say. Cancer can strike anyone at any time. If none of your immediate blood relatives [mother, grandmothers, sisters, aunts] have developed breast cancer, then the chances are low. Your husband's relatives do not enter any equation. What has started you worrying? You can ask to be tested for the BRCA1//BRCA2 genes, but why look for trouble? Much more important is to stop worrying and get on with your life.

Posts.Title: Just Curious

Posts.Content: I am glad they are not making you hang around! Make sure you have someone with you at this appointment - a second set of ears is invaluable. You might like to look at this site: http://www.cancersurvivors.org/Resou...ions.htm#tests It will help you to make a list of questions you want to ask. Don't be afraid to ask; take a notebook with your questions in it and write the answers down. Get the doctor to spell anything you are not sure about. ~Good luck - let us know how it goes.
Posts.Title: sore mouth after chemotherapy

Posts.Content: Welty, I am sorry for you and your mother. Basically the report shows that there is metastatic cancer, probably from a primary in the breast. The bone report states that there are numerous secondaries in the spinal column and the left femur, and in the ribs. Treatment of the bone condition would seem to be the most important step to take, and quickly. It is very easy to miss this unless you are looking for it. My metastasis in the bones was not discovered until a full bone scan was done as part of a battery of tests well after the (late) diagnosis of bc. The symptoms of osteoporosis and bone metastasis could well be confused.

Posts.Content: Hello, Shlomit - how awful for you. I am surprised that chemo has not already been used. It is normal here to reduce the tumour and control the mets as soon as possible. Tamoxifen will not stop aggressive cancer development. It is designed to interfere with oestrogen and its development, and to maintain a steady state. When you ask what should you do now, do you mean in terms of finding out what will happen under chemo? Or do you mean you want to find out what the doctors are thinking? You need to find out what kind of cancer this is, what stage it is at, what possible treatments are available. Here is a good place to start looking: http://breastcancer.about.com/od/def...definition.htm

Posts.Title: Help Regarding Follow Up After Chemotherapy and Radiation.

Posts.Content: There seems to me a grave danger that one can become obsessed by medical tests. There is strong evidence that cancer markers are not in fact particularly useful and certainly cannot indicate metastasis in itself. There has also been argument that overuse of scanners can itself lead to tumour development. So at the end of the day, so long as the oncologists keep an eye on the situation and so long as the patient is aware of his or her own body's behaviour I would be inclined to stop worrying, keep a check on diet and exercise levels, and get on with life. Prevention techniques will be a good way forward.
Posts.Title: Help Regarding Follow Up After Chemotherapy and Radiation.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by christinagale My aunt is suffering from breast cancer she is getting weak and weak day by day any suggestion for me how i can help her? There is not really enough information to help us. How long has she had BC? What treatment[s] has she had? Has she developed metastatic BC in other parts of the body? It sounds as though she is off her food, in which case seeking the help of the team treating her is the first thing to do. People being treated by chemotherapy often suffer anorexia as a side-effect, and there are ways of helping, such as special drinks which can be used either on their own or as ingredients in other things. If you can give us more, maybe more specific advice can be given.
Posts.Title: Help me

Posts.Content: Hi - I am so sorry you have had this diagnosis on top of everything else. One option you have is not to have surgery. You have the right of decision. I think you need to talk to someone about all the possible options and what their effects are before agreeing to a mastectomy. It is particularly important to consider the effects on your quality of life. I did not have a mastectomy, so cannot comment on its effects and dangers, preferring to go the route of management through chemo and hormonals. So far, apart from skin mets, the situation is relatively static. But one is always on a knife edge with cancer. Keep us informed. Best wishes
Posts.Title: An older woman with breast cancer.

Posts.Content: Hi - It all sounds most uncomfortable! From your account of the various symptoms and the interpretation of the scans, there may be an element of infection. At the same time, until the biopsies are through, you really can't tell for sure. I presume that the information about your mother and aunt was recorded, so the doctor will be aware of possibilities. If the biopsies show non-malignancy, yes, you should be able to forget it. The majority of lumps are benign. However, if you go on having problems with your lymph system, you will need to investigate why.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Neeshu Jain Hi Friends, I thanks everyone who is linked with this forum. I have a query for breast cancer problem, Last month was very painful for me as My mother in law observerd symptoms of breast cancer and finally it was diagnosed as the same, later she went through an operation and the affacted portion was removed. But samethime I heard(from the doctors even) that this problem can be genetic too which really make me worry. Can anyone pls share his\her experience or thoughts on it..? or if it is true then is there any precautionary treatment for this which can reduce the chances .. thanks in advance! Neeshu Hi - there is a test to identify if a person has the faulty gene. Since your mother-in-law is not a blood relative, the people who would need to check are any sisters in law that you might have. It cannot skip across from one family to another. As for yourself, do not worry about it, eat a healthy diet [not too many animal proteins, not too many string spices, good balance of vegetables, fruit and carbohydrates], and keep yourself reasonably fit. Be careful about supplements as a healthy diet should provide all that you need in the way of minerals and other micronutrients. If you feel lassitude, it is worth checking blood levels for possible anaemia or low level thyroid function. I hope your MiL is getting better and that there is no further trouble.

Posts.Content: That's right. That is the standard in most NHS treatment centres. Scans would not be ordered unless there was a suspicion of something developing. As to breast screening, there is much discussion about its value below the age of 50 here or over 70. There is [as always in the NHS] an element of economics but also a belief that below the age of 45, regular screening is not a useful diagnostic tool. However, there is a lobby group pushing hard for mammograms to apply to women as young as 25. Incidentally, I checked out the NHS information and find I misremembered their guidelines - it is every three years unless there is a reason for more frequent checks. I am off the register now, so had not kept up to date.

Posts.Content: One of the problems with mammograms is that the tissue in the breast of young women is dense, and that therefore it is less likely that a problem is identified merely from the mammogram itself. That is why there is so much emphasis on regular [emphasise "regular"] self-examination. Until a means of scanning is developed that is more sensitive and less invasive, I suspect that restrictions on using mammograms will continue. There are hopeful signs of new techniques being developed that will be viable and will not be restricted by age.

Posts.Content: That is a simplistic view. Chemotherapy takes many forms, consists of many different drugs, and is used for various different cancers. It is not usual to use chemotherapy over a very long period because of its side-effects. These days oncologists can usually target fairly precisely the treatment to the condition. Chemo is often used to shrink a tumour before surgical interference. It can also be used to treat metastatic cancers and keep their development under control. From your post it seems that the lady has metastatic cancer, in which case [unless there is a remarkable discovery very soon] the doctors will seek to control her condition for as long as possible.

Posts.Title: hormone therapy

Posts.Content: I am glad you have found it helpful. How do I cope? I am thankful that it is so very slow, so that on the whole I am not constantly aware of possible change apart from in the skin, where one form of mets was established early. Skin mets are incredibly difficult to deal with, and extremely irritating [literally], but you are immediately aware of changes. I also have a very elderly mother who lives on her own in a cottage in the country, so I am much occupied in making sure that all is well there. She is selling up and moving into care so my life is about to take another change. She and I have done everything together since my father died, and I am now facing the situation that I will not have her company on holiday or to talk about the past. I also elected to go private early on when it became clear that there was no consistency in the oncology team as it was a teaching department, so registrars and housemen moved every six months, and so have a good ongoing relationship with my oncologist. When not in actual treatment I have 3 monthly check-ups. But if something seems to be happening I go and see her at once. Staying positive - I am still alive 6 years after diagnosis, and so far [unless things change internally] look like living a "normal" life span. I see no point in worrying about when I might succumb. That will come in its own time. As I have an older brother with a far more debilitating chronic condition, who determinedly ferries his daughters around all over the country, goes to horse shows with them and his wife, and firmly will not give in, I have a very good example to live up to. As the song goes "Look on the bright side of life". Not that I do not have depressed moments - I do, but they are only moments and can usually be suppressed. I think it is often harder for the children to have a positive view. After all, it is their parent who is under threat. Being honest about one's fears and concerns is a good step to take. Remember, the Macmillan Nurses are there for you as well if you need to talk things out. One final point - this forum has been wonderful to be a part of, and also very humbling. There are people here who have been through so much, faced so much, and still manage to be there for those facing a bleak world, maintaining a strength of mind that is quite amazing. Most of them are so amazingly SANE.
Posts.Title: Is it normal to not want to remove a metastasised tumor?

Posts.Content: Hi, just wanted to say I too was Stage IV on diagnosis and therefore no operation was carried out. I've been on Aromatose Inhibitors and hormone treatments, and have had two rounds of chemo. I am just facing another round of treatment as the cancer seems to be moving - investigations under way. Diagnosis was Jan 2003, and so far things have been pretty much controlled. I agree with Muttsmom - if you are not happy with your oncologist, find another. It is vital to trust your doctor.
Posts.Title: IP6 supplement

Posts.Content: When I was first diagnosed, my cancer had already metastasized. I had a round of FEC to reduce the tumour, at the end of which the full extent of spread had been established. On considering the options, I elected not to have the tumour excised and the surgeon agreed with great rapidity. My cancer is not static, but slow, and is being held by chemo and hormone treatment. The hormone treatment for me has been the least successful. Chemo is a bore, but it does work. When really down one day I asked my oncologist whether I should not have had the operation. Sh looked at me and said, "You would be in exactly the same situation today". You ask if it is normal not to operate - I would judge that with secondaries there is a reluctance since the cancer has spread already, and if they can control the new tumour [and even reduce it] with other treatment, then that may well be preferred. Surgical intervention has its own dangers and problems. Sadly it seems your mother is prone to cancer development. However things are changing all the time, and it may well be that in the next few years something will prove successful in controlling tumour development. If you are really not happy with the medical approach, could you seek a second opinion, maybe from the Marsden?

I suggest your aunt consults an audiologist in case there is a solid wax plug that can be extracted. Some chemos have known effects on hearing.
Posts.Title: Loss of Hearing after treatment

Posts.Content: Hi, Kat - so sorry about the situation. Do not be too frightened about the chemo and possible side-effects. Eveyone is slightly different and many do not suffer the serious ones. Nausea and hair-loss and the most likely, and both have well-tried systems of management in place. I would say that if hair-loss is a fear, then have your hair cut really short before you start - it helps you to get used to the look, and if there is loss, it is far less traumatic than handfuls of long hairs. After the chemo is over, the hair will grow back (with possible minor changes in texture!) Nausea is usually controlled by additional regimes, but there are also many complementary techniques, such as taking ginger, which can also help. You are probably very wise to have a prophylactic mastectomy. I am sure others with experience of chemo and its effects will add to anything I have to say.

Posts.Content: Hi - welcome to the forums. The first thing to say is STOP READING THE INTERNET until you have a definite diagnosis. Fear is worse than reality. Posts.Title: Newly Found Lump, just looking for advice..

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Sarah Charles Hi Nicole, hopefully your lumps will turn out to be benign. However, if not, time is of the essence since you are so young and breast cancer in young women with a family history tends to be aggressive. Therefore, I would suggest, find out from the technician how soon the followup mammograms and sonograms will be read (the reports describing the results should be ready within 2 or 3 days at most) and go in person to pick up the reports (it is your right to do so -- every center has a procedure for doing this, they're used to it and don't hassle you -- usually it just involves signing a form). Then read the reports. They may be confusing, but will have a summary section at the end. If the report contains a recommendation for any kind of follow up (they may or may not mention the word biopsy), then contact your doctor and get a referral to an appropriate doctor such as an oncologist ASAP. If it is necessary and if you push hard enough (and you should), you may be able to get a biopsy within two weeks. Breast biopsies are done either with a needle or by cutting out a small amount of tissue. Neither procedure is very painful for most women and they do not cause a lot of scarring or disfigurement. Results again will only take a few days at most. Then you'll know. It's better to know. In my case, my mother died of breast cancer, so I was having regular mammograms which always came up clean. However, I finally had a suspicious mammogram and didn't get the results for months. I never got the postcard telling me to come in for a followup. I had tried calling for the results and got the wrong answer. One of my teenage sons came to me with a lump in his armpit when I was on chemotherapy. Very upsetting on many levels, let me tell you. Long story short, I'm in remission after four years and my son's lump was benign. I would also like to suggest that you join a high risk breast cancer program at university-based breast cancer center even if your lumps turn out to be benign (as is most likely). This is for women who are high risk but have not developed breast cancer. They will follow you as closely as you need to be and they have the latest information concerning rare and high-risk breast cancer. Once you are set up with them and figure out your breast cancer screening schedule, put it on your calendar. Then you can go on with your life and not think too much about breast cancer. You've taken care of it in a sense and can compartmentalize this part of your life. So you won't have constant anxiety. Right now, I know it's a very anxious time and I wish you all the best. Exercise doesn't spread cancer and can be a good way to cope. Sarah All very helpful - providing the OP is in the US. It does help to know that as things are not run in the same way in the UK or Europe.

Posts.Content: First - there is still no understanding of the causes of cancer. If there was, then its treatment would be more effective. Milk in this country cannot have IGF added to it, whereas in the US it is the norm in cattle feed. It is always better, where possible, to use organically produced foodstuffs. It is also probably better to obtain raw food rather than treated food [milk is generally pasteurized]. I see no difference in the effectiveness of treatment according to what I am eating. As to milk consumption, having grown up in the 1950s when all schoolchildren were given free milk daily, I have drunk my fair share of it. At school, though, our milk came direct from a farm so was not treated.

Posts.Content: Hi - you need someone whose has been through mastectomy to talk you through the operation and its effects. I am sorry - I can't help you on that score. Your existing conditions also add a factor that is difficult to assess for an outsider. Do you have your daughter with you at your consultations? If not, perhaps this time you should ask her to go with you. A second pair of ears can be extremely helpful. Also, work out on paper what questions you want to ask, ask them and write the answers down. It is valuable to have a record to refer back to. It is worth pointing out that if you are not entirely happy about the proposed treatment, you can seek another opinion. Not all surgeons and oncologists necessarily agree and it can be helpful to get a different view. It is really hard, being told that it is your decision what to do! I usually chicken out and ask my oncologist what she sees as the best way forward. However, this time she has firmly placed the ball in my court about two options and I am having to take the decision. I'm not good at that - always convinced afterwards that I should have taken the other route. Keep talking to us - someone is usually around.

Posts.Title: SOY product and BREAST CANCER

Posts.Content: Hi, just wanted to say I too was Stage IV on diagnosis and therefore no operation was carried out. I've been on Aromatose Inhibitors and hormone treatments, and have had two rounds of chemo. I am just facing another round of treatment as the cancer seems to be moving - investigations under way. Diagnosis was Jan 2003, and so far things have been pretty much controlled. I agree with Muttsmom - if you are not happy with your oncologist, find another. It is vital to trust your doctor.
Posts.Title: IP6 supplement

Posts.Content: Hi Jayme, I have followed your posts with interest and am so glad your MIL has finally agreed to seek help. You ask how can someone leave it so long - many many women do. When I was diagnosed it was basically not a surprise. I had known for some time that something was wrong, but life got in the way. I was too busy. The surgeon who was at that time treating me said he had known many cases where cancer had been firmly ignored. I think also that there is still a residual fear that a diagnosis of breast cancer is an inevitable and rapid death sentence, particularly for older people who remember the time in the past when the only treatment was mastectomy. Modern treatments can do a great deal to extend life and I do hope that something can be found to help.

Posts.Content: This is a cap which is fitted with a cooling system that reduces the temperature of the head to around 8 degrees C. It placed on the head when chemo is being given. The theory is that the hypothermic effect reduces the effect of chemo drugs on the hair follicles. It can reduce hair loss. It works fully for some people. For others there is some hair loss but much less than would normally be expected. And some find that the agony of freezing the head is worse that losing the hair. There is no guarantee. The only advice possible is try it and see, but do not be surprised if it does not work.

Posts.Title: Scan results tomorrow

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by acyunne and she explained that because below 30's the breast cells were still growing and the result of the mammograph will be blurred by it... IS THAT TRUE?? my question is, what should I do? convince her to take a surgery which she's very very afraid of??? or do a mammograph instead of surgery???. can a mammograph be obtained for her ages??? Hi - the doctor is correct. Young women's breast tissue is dense, and mammograms are not efficient at scanning the tissue. Ultrasound is more effective for this purpose in young women. If you seriously think there should be further examination, you should discuss with the doctor whether to do a CT scan, but she may well discourage you as the costs are high. As to the surgery problem, it is good that the tumours are benign, but your fiancee would be well advised to have a lumpectomy, removing them and allowing for a biopsy which would then confirm the diagnosis. I hope you and she can resolve this matter. Do let us know what happens.

Posts.Title: possible breast cancer

Posts.Content: Hello, Kristin, You have asked a difficult question. Everyone reacts so differently to being offered support, and it is hard to know when to stop. However, my own response is to say that getting your affairs into order actually can be a relief as it removes a persistent nagging worry as to "what is going to happen". Making a will and planning for her children's future may seem negatives, but in fact I feel they will help everyone, and the sooner they are resolved, the better. I would also say that she should continue to plan her daily life as if she was to live forever and not pay any attention to depressing medical pronouncements that she will be unable to do something in seven months' time that she wants to do. As you say, many women do live much longer than the gloomy prognosis given to them. You can best support by being an ear. Someone who can be talked at and to, and who is non-judgemental or keeps their counsel until asked for it, is a lifeline.

Posts.Title: the best Chemo treatment for my sister

Posts.Content: Complementary therapies on chemo are a massive topic. People have their own methods of coping. I take a small range of supplements - Resveratrol, CoQ10 [100mg per day], Cod liver Oil, a multivitamin once weekly. Four days before chemo treatment I take Astragalus to boost the white cells. They maintain my general health, which helps to counteract chemo effects. Dealing with specific side-effects is more difficult. There are a number of emollients that can be used on skin disruptions. There is very little to be done about neuropathies apart from painkillers. There is a "cold cap" treatment [done while having the chemo infusions] which many claim prevents hair loss. I gave it up as more uncomfortable than losing my hair, but if it can be borne, it is worth trying. I believe that cold compresses on hands and feet can reduce nail loss, but that is more difficult to arrange during the chemo infusions. I am sure others will have their own experiences to share. One thing I would advise is be very, very cautious about miracle products, and make sure the oncology team are fully aware of what is being done.
Posts.Title: Complimentary Treatments for AC+Taxol Side Effects?

Posts.Content: Hi - sorry you have had to join us. My cancer was diagnosed owing to pleural effusion. Over several months the fluid was drained off, ending with a pleurodysis, which is where the pleural cavity, having been drained, is filled with talc that then sets, preventing the fluid building up. It is generally a relatively easy and successful process. Your SiL shold have lots of time in hand. You do not day what, if any, treatment is being carried out at present.
Posts.Title: Pleural Effusion

Posts.Content: Hi, Emma. Sadly, these days, more young people do seem to be presenting with cancer. The process of chemo to shrink the tumour before surgery is quite usual, and your concerns are quite normal. Surprisingly, you will find that you can cope - when it starts happening. It is sometimes more difficult to deal with your loved ones and their reactions that with your own treatment and condition. The hair loss will depend on your chemo. If it is FEC, then yes, you may well lose your hair. But it grows back. It is VERY rarely more than a temporary loss. Before starting the chemo, go to your usual hairdresser, explain your concern and have your hair cut really short. The shock of loss is much reduced if the hair is not normal length. There is something called the "cold cap" which you can wear while having your chemo infusions. It almost freezes the scalp, theoretically preventing the chemicals from reaching the follicles and thereby reducing on hair loss. Personally I found it more painful than the treatment. Others have persisted and found it helpful. Your oncology/chemo team should be able to tell you about this. Also, see here: http://www.cancernet.co.uk/hairloss.htm The side-effects of the chemo vary according to the individual. You can check them on sites such as: http://www.chemocare.com/bio/ OR http://community.breastcancer.org/ It is important to have someone with you who can take on board what is said when you see the medical team. If your mother is finding it difficult, is there anyone else who could come? also, keep a notebook - write any questions you may have in that, and write the answers to them underneath. In the meantime, here is a site specifically for young people with cancer which may offer you support: http://i2y.com/ In the meantime, keep in touch and let us know how things go. If you can tell us the precise diagnosis it would help. Good lcuk - we are all rooting for you.

Posts.Title: My Mum has developed Liver cancer Secondaries

Posts.Content: Hi Caz. Your mother seems to have a wonderfully supportive and caring health team as well as a supportive family. My cancer was only diagnosed after I had a period of great breathlessness and persistent cough, diagnosed by my GP as "late-onset asthma". It turned out that my lung cavity on one side contained a massive quantity of liquid, and on testing some of that the cancer sells were identified. Two drains were made, and I have [touch wood] had no further problem. As to the difficulties relating to food, the way in which chemo can affect the taste buds is a bore. It was months before I could drink coffee again, and then only black and in small quantities. Essentially, I would plan for small, frequent snacks of things that she can enjoy, and be prepared to throw away what she can't eat. Foods that slip down without needing chewing are often more satisfactory - thick chicken soup, egg custards, rice pudding with lots of cream and dried fruit in it and flavoured with cinnamon, ice cream, light white fish poached in wine or milk. You could also look into ways of preparing vegetables so that they can be eaten easily. If she can tolerate cake, perhaps you could set out to make a range of banana bread, carrot cake and other cakes with fruit or vegetables in them. As to the planning of her funeral, that's not a bad thing to do - saves a lot of hassle for the family later; and I have been facing an uncle and my mother both saying for the last 6 years, "Well, those are the last Christmas cards I shall send". Yeah, yeah, heard that before, will hear it again My uncle has not passed on, but my mother remains in good health and has just moved herself into a residential home, leaving us to sell her house. My brothers and I regard such comments as gestures and tend to proceed as usual. Anyhow, keep in touch and let us know how things go.
Posts.Title: My mum is dying from secondary breast cancer..its sooo sad

Posts.Content: Firstly it may not be cancer. Secondly, if there is a lump they will assess it and probably do a lumpectomy to remove it, followed by a biopsy to establish whether there is cancer or not. If there is cancer, then they will offer radiotherapy and/or chemotherapy to make sure any cancerous cells have been destroyed. If there is no sign of cancer, then she will need no further treatment. I hope the second mammogram shows that it is only a cyst.

Posts.Content: Hi, Destta. I am sorry you have been having a bad time. You need to talk to your medical team about how to cope with the effects of the chemo - they can do all sorts of things to help. If you can get through these 8 cycles, I would do so, just to shrink the tumour as much as possible. They could also discuss alternative chemos with you. There is no proven "natural" cure - lots of anecdotal stories. There is a group of women who have elected not to follow the chemo route who run a site that you might like to look at: http://www.breastcancerchoices.org/ A poster on a UK breast cancer board, who has just been through pre-surgery chemo, has notified us that she took this http://www.lifemelusa.com/ and had no problems with her chemo. No recommendations, but have a look and think about it. I am seriously considering it for my next lot of chemo.

Posts.Title: Dealing with issues other than chemo, but making progress!

Posts.Content: Hi, VLC - so sorry that the beast is growling. Do you mean diets to counter cancer? There is much discussion about this, and very little hard evidence. The most general position would be to avoid red meats and dairy as much as possible, to increase intake of pulses and grains, vegetables and fruit, and to investigate what trace element supplements will be required. The extreme position is something like the Gerson regime, which is time consuming, expensive and requires great commitment, being based on a high level of juicing. There is an argument going on as to whether "organic" produce is better for you, which again is unproven. However, where possible I do prefer to use it as I know that it has to be produced to a stringent criterion and without chemicals or antibiotics. If I can get home-grown vegetables or fruit, then I grab them with a big smile. Whatever you do, make sure your medical team know all about it.

Posts.Content: Hi, it is not really possible to offer diagnosis in this kind of situation. It is generally said that breast cancer does not present as pain, though pain can be a symptom. Try not to worry and also I really do advise keeping off the reading until you have a diagnosis! Reading about medical conditions is the best way to develop the symptoms - medical students often do. From your description it could well be hormonal in some way. Let us know how things go. We are always ready to provide as much support as we can.

Posts.Content: Hi, Maggie, I am sorry for your MiL's situation. I am not sure what information you are looking for, but from your account the primary tumour has been excised, the lymph nodes removed which slightly implies that there are signs of the cancer moving into the lymph system, and the radiotherapy will be to kill off any rogue cells left. At her age any major treatment is a strain on the system, and I advise you to look carefully at the possible side-effects of radiotherapy and what can be done to make them easier to bear. One thing to do is obtain top quality aloe vera gel or ointment which often helps to reduce the burning after radiotherapy. The other thing is to try and get to meet her medical team in order to discuss with them what is being done and what the prognosis is. Do you have sister[s]-in law? If so, you need to liaise with them. Keep us in touch with how things go.
Posts.Title: Brest Cancer

Posts.Content: Hi - I can only suggest that you have a natural resistance to lidacaine, which means it takes a longer time for it to take effect. Biopsy are uncomfortable enough without an additional pain. I do hope that after all your trouble, it proves to be non-malignant.

Posts.Content: Where do you live? And can you tell us more about your wife's diagnosis? Looks as though you should be in the Lung Cancer forum rather than Breast Cancer.
Posts.Title: medicine for NSCLC

Posts.Content: Itching is so unbearable! I was told by someone that you should avoid scratching an itch. Instead, you should tap gently on the spot with the tips of the fingers. Apparently that satisfies the nerves. Worth a go to relieve discomfort.
Posts.Title: Itching please help!!!!!

Posts.Content: Hi - It underlines my belief that if you feel something is wrong, do not allow the doctors to override you! My doctor told me I had developed asthma when what I had was fluid-build up in the lungs as metastasis of breast cancer. It was my insistence on having an X-ray that led to diagnosis. I do hope that now you will receive proper attention and care. And don't hesitate to argue if you are not convinced.
Posts.Title: Itching please help!!!!!

Posts.Content: Hi - I am not sure I can answer that question. If there is ulceration in the breast together with secondaries in the liver, lungs and spleen, and she will not accept any treatment, then only the oncologist can tell you what is likely to happen. You can survive with surprisingly little liver, but 80% does sound high, and with the other internal organs involved, my instinct is that this is not a good scenario. I am really sorry.
Posts.Title: metastatic breast cancer to liver

Posts.Content: That is a question that has to be put to the medical team treating her. It is not something an outsider can [or should] answer. So far as I am aware there is nothing against her taking Ensure (which I have used on several occasions following loss of appetite. If it is sugar intake that concerns you, then keep to the savoury forms.
Posts.Title: Brest Cancer

Posts.Content: This is dangerous advice. There is no evidence that such treatments "cure" cancer, and some evidence that they can prolong agony. It is a sad fact of life that is is desperation that leads people to turn to such treatments, and that in this state of mind they can be persuaded to pay out enormous sums of money in the vague hope of #"cure". Please be very very cautious and look carefully at the economics apart from anything else. On a very basic level, my additional costs for supplementary items is running at over 100.00 per month. Fortunately I am able to carry this, but if there is any financial stringency it can be the straw breaking the camel's back.

Posts.Content: Hi - it is hopeless if one cannot feel a trust in the doctor. Seek another one and get a second opinion if you can.
Posts.Title: Microcalcification

Posts.Content: Hi, Eleanor - I am so sorry that it has come to this stage. This site gives a good clear explanation: http://tinyurl.com/4frsj7 It is hard for those coping, but knowing what is happening is a real help. Keep in touch.
Posts.Title: Final days..........

Posts.Content: Sorry you've had to join us. As strongly oestrogen positive, you are a candidate for hormonal treatments (that will be the pill your onc. was talking about). You don't say what IV treatment is being suggested. Owing to identification of secondaries, I elected to have no surgery, have had two rounds of chemo, am on tamoxifen, and so far am 4 years post-diagnosis and currently stable. It is difficult to say what is best for another person in these matters. However, you may well want to consider no strong action at this point, if the cancer was fully excised and there were no signs in the nodes. Best of luck with your decision, whatever.
Posts.Title: to treat or not to treat Help on this question please....

Posts.Content: Horrid shock when it first happens! Most people find that head hair starts growing back in the first six weeks after chemo finishes. The hair will grow in differently from your normal hair (it often has an interesting crinkle in it, and the colour may be different) but it will gradually become normal as the chemo leaves the system. Radiotherapy usually only affects the part that is being irradiated.

Posts.Content: It's no good saying don't worry - you will, whatever! However, you are taking the right action and seeing a doctor. The chances are that it will be some kind of benign growth like a cyst or a fatty nodule, so here's hoping that you will be posting soon to say it is all ok. Posts.Title: Found strange lump under my breast

Posts.Content: She has been getting alot of visitors, do you think we should limit the people calling to see her? I think it would be good thing to keep the visits short and relatively few. 20 minutes is usually quite long enough for most people in hospital. She is also not sleeping very well (she was never good to sleep in the first place) but as the drains are in her right, that is the side she usually falls asleep on, it is making things that little more uncomfortable. You need to sort this out with the hospital. Do you think she needs time to herself to think and deal with the operation, to mourn her breast? She needs time to herself anyhow - goes back to your question about limiting visits. [b]Yesterday i think was the first time my dad spent some time alone with her and i think he feels awkward around her. How do i help him see she is still Mam, only one breast less. By being quite unemotional about it and talking about her as normal. With due respect, he has known her longer than you have! My question is, what can i say to her what can i do for her to let her know its ok to cry, its ok to hurt and its alright to talk about it? I have to ask - do you think she wants to cry? I feel you must let her decide. The most you can do is to tell her that you are always available if she wants to talk about anything. I am from Ireland and the irish way of dealing with things is sweep everything under the carpet and hope for the best. But i am don't want that, i want my mother to be able to express herself she needs to. Same as above [u]Also what can i say to my dad i don't think he is dealing to well with this, what can i do? I need help to get my family to open up and talk if not it will divide us and we need to be united for this fight. Be upfront - make it clear that everyone is in this together, and ask what they propose to do in order to help your mother get well quickly. Has anyone gone through what i am going through has anyone any advice on what to say to my mother to get her to open up and talk, what to say to my dad. Do i sit him down and explain what my mother has gone through and what the next steps are? I would advise that you be careful. Don't push too hard. Make sure they know you are ready to listen if they want to talk, but if you push, they may well become resistant and angry. Use your anger against the disease. Good luck.
Posts.Title: Help me cope to help my mother and family

Posts.Content: Hi - don't allow yourself to be too scared. Make sure you are not in physical contact with her, and keep your hands well washed. Most colds are picked up via the hands. I had a problem on my first round of chemo which landed me in hospital - my blood count went down and bugs I was already harbouring took hold. I asked for advice about keeping away from other people and was firmly told that so long as no-one sneezed or coughed on me, and I was sensible about keeping my strength up, there should be no problem. As to your co-worker, she is the one who should stay home till she is no longer infectious

Posts.Title: My 16 year old has a lump in her breast

Posts.Content: Hi LadyHawk. My instinctive response is that she is 87 and if the cancer is not one of the aggressive ones, then non-interference may well be perfectly satisfactory. At her age, the probability is that the cancer is very slow growing, and unless there are signs of metastasis (which from your account does not appear to be something that has occurred), it could very probably be controlled with hormonal treatments. Get another opinion if you can. The effects of a mastectomy and chemotherapy are pretty dire, and at 87 may not be desirable.

Posts.Title: 87 year old mother diagnosed with breast cancer

Posts.Content: I elected not to have any operations (chickened out, in part), and have had two bouts of chemo(FEC and navelbine), arimidex, and now tamoxifen. So far the tam. is holding things steady, and it's four years since diagnosis. In you case it seems to be evenly balanced as to which will cause you more discomfort and in the end it comes down to what you yourself feel you can bear. Personally, in view of your surgeon's comments, I would go with the chemo plan. Good luck with your decision.
Posts.Title: HELP!!! I NEED YOUR OPINION...I'M REALLY CONFUSED....

Posts.Content: I am sorry for your mother and her situation, and sympathise with your distress. You say she has advanced breast cancer. Can you give more details of her situation? I take it that the cancer has metastasized? At the risk of seeming hard, I must emphasise that if she has been through the gamut of treatments, it is most unlikely that anything can be done. Many people turn to alternative treatments as a last resort, by which time it is too late.
